abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Lifelong Learning and
            Training Project for Chile were as follows: outcomes were
            satisfactory, the risk to development outcome was moderate,
            the Bank performance was satisfactory, and the borrower
            performance was also satisfactory. Some lessons learned
            included: lifelong learning and training is crucial both
            from equity and efficiency perspectives. In the context of
            Chile's lifelong learning and training system, the
            development of human capital is solidly grounded in the
            country's needs to support its integration into the
            world economy as well as its social deficit. An adequate
            lifelong learning and training system necessarily involves
            diverse players that are in themselves heterogeneous, both
            in the public and private spheres. The success of Chile
            Califica was not the result of having a strong champion with
            high visibility within the public or private spheres who
            advocated for the development of a lifelong learning and
            training system. Rather, it was the result of gradually
            introducing an overall framework that addressed many of the
            weaknesses in the existing educational and training system
            in a comprehensive and integrated manner. Although the
            implementation of the project at the regional level resulted
            in added complexity, it ensured its relevancy at the
            regional level. While other developing countries can
            certainly learn from this innovative project, Chile's
            special characteristics mean that these ideas cannot be
            exported easily or wholesale.
